Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as 7754c5cd8e8fb5b97c246fb6ffb6b3642ef4d5dd
@patrick@stwcx.xyz Hi Patrick, could you help review it? Thanks!

I see sections missing from this document based on the design document template.  For example, it seems like you're going to be requesting a new repository and there is some questions in the current template that talk about code organization.  Please check over the template and add any missing sections.

Only one subsection " ### Organizational" under "Impacts" is missing. I will add it in the newer version.

So far, this design doc only requires changes in existing repos:
   - https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb
   - https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces
   
In the future, we may create a reference dbus daemon that does SPDM attestation in a different repo, but it is optional.
lowercase.  This isn't an acronym.
Ack
Can we link to the spec instead of DMTF?
Ack

Are there any hardware protocols you are focused on?  Or does SPDM work on any MCTP end-point?  It looks to me like there are multiple protocols listed on the DMTF website, so you should be clear about what you're planning to support.  (I see MCTP, "Storage", and TCP bindings listed on DMTF's website.)

There are multiple transport layer protocols that can carry SPDM messages. For example, Libspdm support a SPDM + MCTP binding and also a SPDM + PCIe-DOE binding. The transport layer protocol should be transparent to bmcweb  and dbus interfaces design. 

We can separate the D-Bus daemon into two parts, the upper part provide interfaces to expose SPDM related properties, like links to device certificates, method to get measurements; the lower part manage the connection with a SPDM responder device.
Only the D-Bus daemon lower part will need to decide how it wants to talk to the SPDM-capable device (the responder) : through MCTP or PCIe DOE.

This design doc will be focusing on the upper part of dbus daeson(dbus interfaces) and bmcweb changes. It is not binded to a certain transport layer protocol, like MCTP or PCIe DOE.
It's unfortunate they've named this action based on the specific protocol.
Yes, the parameters and return format for the method is quite specific to SPDM though.

We should NOT be linking to raw PLDM resources here.  The PLDM resource should have been translated into a normal Inventory object before your daemon gets ahold of it.

There is not a single existing code reference to Source.PLDM.FRU in the whole openbmc organization.

I see.

On the consumer side(BMCWeb/Redfish), they need to query about "SKU", "Serial Number", "Manufacturer", "UUID" and so on, most of which has been implemented as property in FRU interface. To gather these info, can we make the following assumption?:
 1) Some Inventory object created for the trusted component and implement the FRU interface;
 2) BMCWeb will be able to find the associated object for the trusted component object and gather information about the trusted component from there.

After reading about the discussion on Source/PLDM/FRU(https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/+/32533) I now have a better understanding. I have rephrased this part and removed the link to PLDM resources.
How will it know to do these things?

The daemon that manage the TrustedComponent and ComponentIntegrity objects will have the information to initialize these objects.

For example, for a GPU dbus daemon, it can create the dbus objects during initialization for the GPU root of trust element.
lowercase
Ack
Can't this be improved?
It makes sense for the original use cases. For example, one HTTPS server only need to manage one certificate/certificate chain.
I don't think this is true.  Otherwise we couldn't support mTLS.
On the server side, the cert manager needs access to the private key to perform sign (CSR) request. When create a cert manager (for HTTPS), it asks about the path to the private key.
nit: sp
Ack

You use the word "certificate management" here, but is there really "management" being done?  Aren't you just advertising the certificate that the device presents to you?  What kind of management is there?

(Please elaborate on this in the document if you want to continue to use the word "management").

So for the device certificate, there isn't much management service: only minor "management" if you count create and replace as management service.

I will rephrase it to make it more clear.

I don't think `systems` is a good choice.  The SPDM isn't associated exclusively with a system and I don't know what valid values are for `{systemId}`.  A shared NIC, in a multi-host design, can support SPDM.  The SPDM certificate is associated to the NIC and not to any single system.

For the certificates, we only need a place to put all device certificates. I would prefer a flat structure to simplify the searching. When we have one system, it is Ok to put all device certificates under this one system. There is no need to create a complex hierarchy under systems/ for certificates.

If a NIC is shared among multiple systems, would it be ok to have a certificate object copy under both system/ directory? 

In summary, we just want to create a new category under "/xyz/openbmc_project/certs/" to put device certificates. Using "systems" help us to create a relatively simple structure. 

The systems example comes from the Redfish Resource and Schema Guide (https://www.dmtf.org/sites/default/files/standards/documents/DSP2046_2022.3.pdf, page 226).

I think it is a little awkward to require direct naming here to match.  Is Ed aligned with that?

The "Systems" objects are driven by entity-manager config / detection.  I think the SystemId we currently use (since multi-host isn't fully supported) is just a static name, but in the not too distant future this will be driven by specific Inventory and/or State objects being present.

I'm not familiar with the naming of systems here. It is intuitive to use the "system" same name in the Redfish resource path, otherwise, we need to create a lookup table for mapping them. 

@Ed, could you help provide directions here?

These are not how we name dbus paths.  The Chassis stuff is under /xyz/openbmc_project/inventory usually and doesn't necessarily have hierarchy.  

I don't know what {ChassisId} refers but shouldn't that be an association?

Actually, I'm not sure about the convention of how we organize the dbus objects. Especially for the trusted component and component integrity objects, as they are new schema to be implemented. I am trying to give an example by mimicking how Redfish organize the resources. But I am open to follow any D-Bus convention of organizing these new type of objects.

I think association make sense here. My question is: should we create a directory for component integrity objects and trusted component objects? For example:

- `/xyz/openbmc_project/ComponentIntegrity/{ComponentIntegrityId}
- `/xyz/openbmc_project/TrustedComponent/{TrustedComponentId}`
- `/xyz/openbmc_project/certs/systems/{SystemId}/{CertId}`

In BMCWeb, we can reconstruct the following structure info by query the association information of Chassis:
`/redfish/v1/Chassis/{ChassisId}/TrustedComponent/{TrustedComponentId}`

I hope we're not going down a path that we have device-specific SPDM daemons??  That isn't clear until I get to the very bottom of this document.

SPDM goes over standard protocols, such as MCTP.  Why would we need anything device specific in this daemon, other than maybe the discovery pieces?
"Can we create a device neutral SPDM daemon?" is non-trivia question, I will address it by adding more information in the design doc.

We need to have good unit tests in this new proposed repository.

Ideally we would add system integration tests in to openbmc-test-automation.
If we include the dbus daemon, yes, we need system integration tests. If it is only about the bmcweb and dbus interfaces changes, the Redfish Service Validator seems to be sufficient to me.
Adding Nan Zhou, Nancy Yuen, Richard Hanley to help with the review, thanks!
Will you be providing a dbus daemon implementation?

Yes, we plan to provide a library and a demo dbus daemon. The dbus daemon will use the library, but also needs to implement device-specific way to talk to the device.

The demo dbus daemon and library will be a second step following the spdm support in bmcweb and D-Bus interfaces.

Where is the device specific information coming from?
Is it from entity-manager's json config, or from other daemons that manage devices supporting SPDM?

It should be other daemons that manage devices supporting SPDM. As explained earlier, we do not provide a generic SPDM daemon implementation. We intend to provide a library to help with implementing the SPDM daemon as it really depends on the what device it is and how it is connected to the BMC (via, PCIe, or MCTP) when it comes to device initialization and transport layer initialization.
Ack

entity-manager is the standard way to do both of these in OpenBMC.  it's important to include entity-manager and maybe example of how it fits in, for the rest of users who could adopt this.

What you describe here is essentially a prober.  And the subsequent points sound like the corresponding reactor.

So far, in my prototype, it is the dbus daemon that does all the steps here.  After a quick look at entity-manager( not familiar with it before) , it seems to be a good fit for scenario. Let me dig more into it and see how it will simplify the implementation.

BTW, it seems to be part of the dbus daemon work, which is a second step. For the first step, I was hoping to focus on adding bmcweb and dbus interface support for spdm.
Is this expected to be done in this daemon or other daemons that manages the device?

This should be done in this SPDM daemon. Typically, this SPDM daemon will call to libspdm library to construct SPDM protocol messages, which will further call into transport layer send/receive function to exchange messages between BMC and the device.

To be clarified, the SPDM daemon can be an independent daemon or it can be a service provided by the device management daemon. In this design, we do not force it into one way or another. Instead, we intend to provide a library to help implement the feature needed by this SPDM daemon.
Ack
System isn't a good descriptor.  Since the cert manager is using /xyz/openbmc_project/certs, maybe this can be something like '/xyz/openbmc_device_certs'
Do you mean `/xyz/openbmc_project/device_certs` ? it seems `/xyz/openbmc_project/` is a prefix for all openbmc related resources.
Updated

Update the design doc after a sync meeting with Jeremy kerr on mctp support. It turns out a single SPDM Daemon is preferable when devices comply with MCTP spec.

Also resolved some issue on certificate management. Now it gets clarified that device certificates can be exposed under certain chassis to comply with Redfish (https://www.dmtf.org/sites/default/files/standards/documents/DSP2046_2022.2.pdf).
Hi Patrick, this design doc has been updated after a discussion with Jeremy Kerr. Now we have agreed on a single SPDM daemon design. Please help take a look, thanks!

Hi Zhichuang, broadly the proposal seems reasonable to me and I don't have any particular architectural concerns. I do have some implementation queries and formatting requests in-line. Thanks for the write-up!
Thanks Andrew for the feedback! Really appreciate it! I've addressed it in the updated version.
Typo: component
Done
Can you please add a link to the implementation?
Done

Can you please mark-up `ComponentIntegrity` and `TrustedComponent` as fixed-width (backticks), that will help them stand out in the rendered document.

Please audit the whole document for this as I've seen a few places where this change could be made.
Done
s/binded/bound/ 😊
Done

I think this motivates some discussion of an (internal?) transport abstraction. Do you have thoughts there? Can you unpack them in the text for us if so?

THe PLDM stack might be a useful reference. In libpldm we provide a transport abstraction that's used by PLDM so most of the code doesn't have to care about how it's talking to a device, only that it can:

https://github.com/openbmc/libpldm/blob/main/include/libpldm/transport.h

An equivalent for SPDM would likely be useful.

Actually, does libspdm support something like that already?

Yes, libspdm also has transport layer binding support, similar to libpldm. I clarified more in the updated version. 

I mentioned the different transport layer here as the spdm daemon needs to support device discovery for various type of transport layer protocols.
Why on the command-line? What's driving that statement? Can we add some more justification there? I have no background on PCIe-DOE though, so this is potentially an ignorant query/request 😊

We need some way to find those devices that support SPDM. For MCTP, the mctpd daemon will enumerate all MCTP devices and allow us to querry whether a certain device support SPDM. So it is easy;

For PCIe-DOE, not all PCIe device support DOE will support SPDM, we can't query about whether a DOE capable device support SPDM (to my knowledge). So it is easier to pass the pci bdf info to the daemon, so that we can directly do DOE discovery based on this info.

Also it is possible to provide PCI device id(VendorId:DeviceId) that we can use it to locate the device's BDF info and do DOE discovery from there.

I'm open for suggestions on how we should support PCIe-DOE devices. So far, providing BDF seems to be the most straightforward one.

Right, but "on the command-line" is a specific implementation of passing that information to the daemon. I think that's a bit too much detail for the scope of the discussion. There are other methods, such as configuration file, or an EM `Exposes` schema. Maybe we could pick one or all of those, but I think that's something we can cover elsewhere.
Agree, the command-line is too specific, updated the design doc to leave it open. Thanks!
Backticks for fixed-width again here.
Done
Backticks for fixed-width again here
Done
Backticks for these objects as well
Done

I think it's a bit much to lead with "As we know ..." and then link to your personal fork of bmcweb which (likely) hasn't yet had any visibility in the OpenBMC community.

I think this should be rewritten to something like:

> [Experimental support for SPDM exists for `bmcweb`](https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/compare/master...sunzc:bmcweb:spdm)
Done

Can we rather integrate this into the sentence text? For instance:

> Note, `libspdm` [already provides a transport layer protocol binding](https://github.com/DMTF/libspdm/blob/main/include/internal/libspdm_common_lib.h#L445-L446) with message encoding/decoding support.
Done

Hi Zhichuang, my primary request is the rewording of the "As we know" phrase, but I also left a comment about the command line parameter stuff for PCIe-DOE.

Thanks for the updates!
Thanks for the suggestions, quite helpful! Addressed the comments in the updated version.
fixed typos
Enumerate
Done
Enumerate
Done
Hi Patrick, there are a couple of +1 now, could you help take a look and give a +2 if it looks good? Thanks!
nit: typo.
Ack
These seem like requirements, not a design.
For the new interface design, the idea here is to first list what we need and then propose new interfaces to support it. Any suggestions?

Maybe this is just how i'm reading the doc, but at this point, "trusted component" isn't really defined.  Does trusted component mean a physical component (an add in card, cpu, ect) or a ROT?  If we're going off the Redfish definition of TrustedComponent (ie a ROT) we need to say that.
It is consistent with the Redfish definition of TrustedComponent, which means "a trusted device, such as a TPM". Let me clarify it in the doc.
should be "cannot"
Acknowledged
How far into the future is this?  @Ed are you ok with accepting a design with no proposed backend?

We should be able to start releasing SPDM daemon patches by the end of Q1'2024. So far, we already have a prototype for the spdm dameon to test BMCWeb. It lacks support for DOE discovery and MCTP EID discovery, we will add these features and send them to upstream.
Can we go ahead and change this text then to suggest we're going to request a new repo?  We probably should open an issue to the TOF to create it also.

Generally designs are intended to be holistic across OpenBMC, not just a single daemons worth of implementation.  As a guideline, we don't check in code into bmcweb without both the interfaces present in PDI and a functional backend being available in OpenBMC.  Not requiring that in the past has caused significant thrash (see bifurcated virtual media implementations).  Happy to discuss if someone thinks there's a way to support a non-upstream backend, but the statement in the doc makes me think the order is incorrect, we should be approving an SPDM backend design first, then follow up with bmcweb which hopefully doesn't even need a design doc, because it's just following the normal DBus -> Redfish conversion rules.

With that said, this design lists unit tests (redfish service validator), and integration tests, so I'm a little surprised that this design doesn't include a backend, given that a backend would be required for any of the below to pass.  "Design for SPDM Attestation D-Bus Daemon, demonstrating how to fetch the attestation results over D-Bus" also would imply that this new daemon would require a repo?

I suspect those two opposing things need clarified in the text of this commit.

Just FYI to all, despite my name being listed as a contributor, I don't have a lot to do with the current implementation anymore, so I will leave it up to others to work through whether a repo is required and either updating the doc with that intent, or getting the repo request started with the TOF.  I'd note that the starter patchset of getting the schemas enabled is here:

https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/61702

Feel free to use that as a starting point, or do your own thing.
Ack
Could you please add a diagram to describe the relationship between components?
I just added a diagram, it should help make it more clear how these components interact. Thanks for the suggestion!
All the inconsistent use of semi-colon has been addressed.
Why the lines are terminated by ; in doc instead of .?
Done

same?
should be changed at other places too in the doc
Done
typo redundancy
Done
D-bus object which implements the ComponentIntegrity object will also implement the SPDMGetSignedMeasurement interface?
Yes

Does that mean SPDM - VCA followed by the Digest/Certificate is done for each device in advance and during D-Bus call to  SPDMGetSignedMeasurement --only GET Measurement will be called no VCA/Digest/Certificate?

If yes , why we are not doing the full SPDM handshake?

VCA will be done during SPDM Daemon initialization and device certificate will be fetched and will be published as a dbus object.

Only GetMeasurements will be called and no VCA.

>If yes , why we are not doing the full SPDM handshake?

The assumption is the device certificate won't be updated lively during bmc boot up time.  What's the concern here?

which application is going to host device certificates? Are you going to create another certificate manager instance for device? We also need to make sure that only SPDM daemon can internally replace the certificate, User should not be able to do through OOB.

SPDM daemon will host device certificate dbus object. It can be fetched over BMCWeb URI `/redfish/v1/Chassis/{chassisId}/Certificates/{certId}`.

Certificate can be marked as readonly. It should not be updated by other dbus daemon. 

We do not expect live certificate update. Technically, SPDM D-Bus daemon should be able to update it if that happens.

>User should not be able to do through OOB.

Could you elaborate it that "user update certificate OOB"?
/redfish/v1/Chassis/{ChassisId}/TrustedComponent/  --> /redfish/v1/Chassis/{ChassisId}/TrustedComponents/<id>
Acknowledged
Any more comments? Or should we move forward with this design?
Hi Zhichuang - thanks for the prompt for reviews. There's been some recent activity around how we configure systems using entity-manager and mctpd. I've left some comments inline around this.
Thanks for the update! The `mctpreactor` sounds like an exciting change! I will update the design doc to reflect the change.
here's a proof-of-concept: [wip: mctpreactor](https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/dbus-sensors/+/69111)

I don't think that we should require a specific schema for a trusted device? I think we can exploit the (already merged) `MCTPEndpoint` schema? Here's a conversation about how we integrate mctpd with EM:

https://github.com/CodeConstruct/mctp/pull/17

I'm working on a proof-of-concept `mctpreactor` daemon in dbus-sensors to handle the configuration.

From there the SPDM daemon should only need to monitor `mctpd` for `InterfacesAdded` signals providing the `xyz.openbmc_project.MCTP.Endpoint` interface, which exposes the message types supported by the endpoint in the `SupportedMessageTypes` member. This way there's no specific support required for SPDM devices in the EM configuration schemas.

I'd like to see this direction incorporated into the document.
I have updated the doc to reflect the change, thanks for the idea!
We shouldn't need any double-checking.
Acknowledged
If we take the approach I suggest above then the diagram changes a little such that the SPDM daemon doesn't interact with Entity Manager, only with `mctpd` and the devices.
Make sense, I replaced the EntityManager with InventoryManager. We need to query InventoryManager for handling PCIe DOE device.
